element_texts.text: Completed

WEDNESDAY, June 6th, 1855.
Left St Louis at 12 O'clock M. on board Steamer "St. Mary" bound for Upper Missouri. -  
A rainy, cold morning - We called at the magazine to take one hundred kegs of powder - Our boat draws 18 inches light, is 600 tons berthed - has on now 250 long and draws 3 feet. -
She is a new boat and quite comfortable - 
We entered the Missouri River at 1/2 past four O'clock - Passed Belle Fontaine at 5 O'clock   still raining very fast - Stopped at 6 O'clock for the night, very dark
Conversed with Mr. Alex Culbertson until 1/2 past 12 O'clock - 
He has been 27 years in the Sioux and Blackfeet Country
Completed

THURSDAY, June 7th, 1855.
Beautiful, clear sky - 
Passed St Charles at 8 O'clock - river rising  Boat running very well 
- We have as passengers Col. A I. Vaughan + son, Alex Culbertson, Mr. Galpin, Col. A. Cumming and his secretary Mr. Roche - My friend Mr. Wilson + myself - 
Capt. of the boat, Le  Barge Chas. Chouteau clerk, and Doct. Robinson physician,
- The steamer "San Cloon" passed us this morning, we passed her about 9 O'clock, she was at a woodyard - She was in sight of us astern all day, and repassed us at 7 O'clock
As our boat is new, our Capt. will not press her -
Completed

Two very similar entries, one written directly on top of the other.
#1
FRIDAY, June 8th, 1855.
Retired last night at 10 O'clock boat laid by - Started on at 2 O'clock this morning but was compelled to lay by again on account of the fog which I found very dense when I arose at 1/2 past six O'clock -  
Cleared off and we started on again at 1/2 past seven - very pleasant day - Practiced shooting rifles for amusement - Col. Cumming brought 10 Sharps rifles with him - fired them very fun gun - throwing a ball an almost incredible distance. -
Passed the mouth of the "Osage" River at five O'clock, Passed "Jefferson City" at 7 O'clock and fifteen minutes,
The "Wm Baird" one of the boats purchased by the U.S to transport supplies to Fort Pierre passed us at 3 O'clock, two others in site astern -
#2
FRIDAY, June 8th, 1855.
Retired last night at 10 O'clock boat stopped for the night -
Started on at 2 O'clock this morning but was compelled to tie up a again on account of the fog which I found still very dense when I arose at 6 O'clock - It soon cleared off and we moved on - 
Col. Cumming brought 10 Sharps rifles with him and we amused ourselves today shooting at snags in the river -
Passed the mouth of the "Osage" River at 5 O'clock and Jefferson City at 7 O'clock 
The Wm Baird one of the boats purchased by government to transport supplies to Fort Pierre, passed us at 3 O'clock  2 others in sight astern
Completed

SATURDAY, June 9th 1855.
Another govt. boat passed us during the night - we travelled all night and are getting along finely - weather delightful - all in good health and spirits - except one of the men below who has fits, brought on by drinking too much - Passed "Boouville" at 7 O'clock A.M. - Passed "Glasgow" at 12 O'clock, M. 
The Captain shot a deer which was crossing the river, Killed him instantly, he sunk and we lost the venison - 
Slight shower about sun down - beautiful  rainbow - and magnificent sun set - prophecying a fine day tomorrow - Passed "Bushwick" at 7 O'clock A.M. - 
Cool delightful evening - A very bad river ahead full of snags and a few wind clouds were flying so the Capt. concluded to lay by
Completed

SUNDAY, June 10th 1855.
Another lovely morning, we laid by until 2 O'clock this morning - when we once more started on our winding way - and a winding way it is, - 
We over hauled, at 8 1/2 O'clock A.M, the "San Cloon" which passed us on the 7th and the "Wm Baird" U.S. which passed us on the 8th - both hard aground on a sand bar near "Hills Landing" - We went over without touching - 
Landed at "Lexington" at 1/2 past 3 O'clock P.M. Laid her one half hour - took in coal - 
Passed the day quietly and pleasantly - 
Men and passengers all in good health and weather delightful
Completed

MONDAY, June 11th 1855.
The weather still continuing clear and pleasant - 
We laid by again last night - The captain says it is best to risk nothing as we have so long a trip before us - Arose this morning at 7 O'clock - 
Three boats passed us last night while we were tied up. - 
Passed "Kansas City" at 2 1/2 O'clock - 3 Steamers in sight ahead - 
Landed at "Parkville" at 5 O'clock - Took on board Maj. Culbertson's wife and a daughter by another wife - very interesting family - 
Bad place in the river and the 3 boats that passed us last night we over hauled
written in left margin wrote letter
Completed

TUESDAY, June 12th, 1855.
Laid by last night and did not start until 7 O'clock this morning on account of fog - four boats in sight Wm Baird ahead - San Cloon and Arabia trying to get over the bar - 
Passed Leavenworth City at 8 1/2 O'clock - Passed the Fort at 9 O'clock - reached "Weston" at 10 1/2 O'clock, Landed Miss Culbertson and Doct C-, who are going to Illinois - also landed Col. Vaughan + son + Mr. Roche who are to get aboard again at St Jo. Joseph - Soon after leaving Weston, saw one old beaver and two young ones - 
We see indians occasionally along the banks - an evidence that we are gradually leaving civilisation -
Completed

WEDNESDAY, June 13th, 1855.
We stopped last evening earlier than usual, on account of being near St. Joseph and we did not wish to be troubled with people from the shore - Started at daylight and arrived at St. J. at 6 O'clock, stopped on the opposite side of the river - fine town but going fast into the river - 
We crossed in the yawl and procured a few stores, took Col. Vaughan, son + Mr. Roche on board again and were off about nine O'clock, passed the Iowa reserve - saw a good many indians along the shore - 
The appearance of this country is improving
Completed

THURSDAY, June 14th, 1855.
We laid by again last night but were off early this morning - passing the Nemaha reserve - 
A message arrived at St. Joseph, while Col. Vaughan was there, from Council Bluffs with a report that 100 emigrant waggons had been cut off and all men and women murdered, except one woman, who was spared by the indians, because she played an accordian - doubtful - shall learn the truth tomorrow at Council Bluffs - 
Stopped at dark for the night, found the no. of waggons had fallen to 13 - think when get to the Bluffs it will be none
Completed

FRIDAY, June 15th, 1855.
Started on at daylight this morning - delightful weather - expect to reach the Bluffs this afternoon - 
Opposite the Mouth of the "Platte" river at 1/2 past two O'clock P.M. - boat stopped - yawl out with eight across sounding for the channel, snags in every direction excessively hot - 
We started out and run up to "St Mary's" before dark, laid near shore at night - 
Sanfoy? says nothing in report that indians had robbed waggons, but says there is like to be trouble, as the indians have ordered traders to leave
Completed

SATURDAY, June 16th, 1855.
Got off early this morning, passed ""Bellevue" at 8 O'clock, after stopping at St Mary's sometime to chip ice +c. etc. Bellevue consists of one house, two barns, - We have had occasional glimpses of the prairies, but today we come in full view of immense prairies stretching away as far as the eye can reach - "Boundless + beautiful" -
We find the water very low, but as our boat draws very little water (3 ft) we do not have much trouble - passed old "Council Bluffs", former site of U.S. Fort, at five O'clock -
Completed

SUNDAY, June 17th, 1855.
We were compelled to stop early last night on account of a storm, The boat was well secured and it was well for us, as another storm came on at 1/2 past 3 O'clcok this morning - We got started at four O'clock run on until 1/2 past eight - stopped at "Soldier Creek" to wood, took on board 30 cords - 
Very fine morning, air cool and refreshing after the storm - 
Commenced getting rain about nine or ten O'clock and proved to be the hottest day we have had since we started -
Completed

MONDAY, Jnne 18th, 1855.
We tied up last night earlier than usual on account of a threatning black cloud in the North west. The storm came on very soon but did not pass directly over us - 
Retired about 11 O'clock - was aroused at 1/2 past 12 hearing Maj. Culbertson exclaim "Well we are going now" - looked out into the cabin and found the passengers nearly all up and under the impression that the boat was loose but it proved to be the yawl only - rain, hail, thunder, lightning and a perfect hurricane blowing, adding interest to the scene. - 
Passed "Blackbird's Hill" at 11 O'clock - met Mackinaw boats near this place at 1/4 of 12 O'clock.
They bring letters from traders above - the trader at "Fort Union says "I cannot get meat and wood although both are in sight of the fort". -
Completed

TUESDAY, June 19th, 1855.
Tied up last night opposite "Searjent's Bluff" (Floyd's Grove)
This was the site of an old govt. fort, long since demolished - A searjent, by the name of Floyd, settled here, died over 20 years since and was buried on top of the Bluff - hence the name - Mr. Galpin left us here to go to Fort Pierre by land in order to arrive before the boat, - we had another heavy gale last night - 
Met two more of the company's boats today - they are from "Fort Sarpy" on the Yellow Stone - 
They bring no further news - loaded with Buffalo robes -
Completed

WEDNESDAY, June 20th, 1855.
We stopped last night to cut wood for the first time - river rising fast - last evening we distributed some "Sharps" rifles cartridges +c. etc. - 
We are getting into the country of the "Poncahs" who are a detached band of Omaha's and said to be bad indians. - 
We passed an indian today - first Sioux - crossed out Pawnee we have seen he had a deer on his back which had evidently killed with his bow and arrow, as he had no other weapon - 
Passed "River au Jacques" at 5 O'clock - 
Slight shower at dark and is quite cool -- sudden change
Completed

THURSDAY, June 21st, 1855
We laid last night within three miles of the lower "Yancton" village - "Smutty Bear" chief - 
I arose at 1/2 past 4 O'clock we ran to the village - only about 20 lodges at home - had council - took chief and four men on board - shall leave them at the next "Yancton" village where the goods for the two bands will be distributed - found Mr. Galpin at "Smutty" "Bears" village, had not gained by taking land route - came on board again is to get off at next village - 
We passed "Poncah" village about 6 O'clock, near the mouth of "L'eau qui court" - river - saw some dead bodies on scaffold, also great number of graves
Completed

FRIDAY, June 22d, 1855.
We arrived at Yancton village at 1/2 past 12 O'clock passed "Town Rock" at 10 O'clock A.M. - 
Stopped at the indian village to distribute arrival presents from U.S. - The Chief is called "The man who struck the Ree" - fine looking men - most of them are large size -
A very pleasant day indeed - arrived at village 12 O'clock
While there a council was held and Col. Cumming gave them some good advice in regard to the course which it would be best for them to pursue the [[coming - crossed out] present summer. - left village at four O'clock
Completed

SATURDAY, June 23d, 1855.
We stopped about fifteen miles above the Indian Village last night - started on early this morning - cool and pleasant - no musquito yet - Our journey today was through a country almost destitute of timber - There being none upon the hills - immense prairies dotted with miniature mountains - 
saw one wolf - it is the first wild animal we have seen since we left Council Bluffs.
The water is falling but very slowly -
We will begin to find game again above Fort Pierre, and am told it is very plenty above fort Union.
Completed

SUNDAY, June 24th, 1855.
Clear, cool morning, but bids fair to be quite warm when the sun gets up - 
We tied up last night at the mouth of the "White River" or "White earth" as it is called on the maps - a very bad bar here but we crossed without much difficulty - 
About one O'clock today lost a man overboard - could not recover his body - Stopped about 11 O'clock at Cedar Island to take woods - at 1/2 past 1 O'clock passed portage of the Great bend of the Missouri - 30 miles around - 2 Miles across - 
Stopped to woods again and laid up for the night -
Completed

MONDAY, June 25th, 1855.
Another delightful morning, Boat started at 1/2 past 3 O'clock - Heard sound of the passengers complaining this morning of having been troubled by musquitos have not seen any myself - 
Passed by Fort Defiance, built by Choteau Chouteau, but since abandoned, at one O'clock P.M. - 
Very hot in the afternoon, indication of a storm but it passed over with only a few drops of rain - we are out of ice and are all looking forward anxiously to our arrival at Fort Pierre where we can get a new supply
Completed

TUESDAY, June 26th, 1855.
Laid up early last night at a cedar island, 40 miles from Fort Pierre Started early this morning but did not get along very rapidly on account of sand bars - 
Passed Fort George (Campbell + co) at 9 O'clock A.M. - 
Arrived at Fort Pierre at 1/2 past 3 O'clock P.M. This has been for many years a trading post of P. Chouteau + co's but was purchased this spring by the U.S. for 45,000. - for a garrison - timber is very scarce and the price fair for the post - enough - 
The company have about 300 head of cattle here and a great number of horses
Completed

WEDNESDAY, June 27th, 1855.
Fine cool morning
Col. Vaughan will distribute the annuity presents to the two Kettle bands of Sioux which will detain us all day probably - 
- After councilling a long time the indians refuse to receive their annuities, giving as a reason that they were afraid of the western indians, after another council with Col. Cumming who gave the two chiefs a medal each, they concluded to receive his goods, which they did : also a part of a band of Yanktonais - 
We concluded our business and left Fort Pierre at 1/2 past three P.M. took a barge in tow on the opposite side of the river
Completed

THURSDAY, June 28th, 1855.
Clear, beautiful morning but bids fair to be the warmest day we have here - 
Thermometer stood a 98 yesterday at 11 O'clock - probably at about 106 in the afternoon
I was awakened this morning at daylight by some person on shore hallooing to the boat just as we were starting, it proved to be a squaw, mother of Mr. Hotekin's Hodgkin's wife who came on board at Fort Pierre - She said she came for her daughter - We did not stop - 
Passed the mouth of the big "Cheyenne" at 1/2 past 5 O'clock P.M. - 
Storm brewing and we tied up early - 
The day was not as hot as we anticipated
Completed

FRIDAY, June 29th, 1855.
A cool morning, fine is very comfortable - Started early but did not get a good distance before we stopped to wood and sent the yawl ahead to look out the channels. - Doct Hayden came on board at Fort Pierre, he is a young man who has been in this country for 2 years searching for curiosities in the way of birds, bugs, petrifactions +c. etc. - This country abounds in prickly pear - so that is almost impossible for a person unaccustomed to them to travel without getting the thorn in his foot - A cold day with an occasional sprinkle of rain - -
Completed

SATURDAY, June 30th, 1855.
This is one of the most unpleasant mornings since we left St Louis - cold + rainy. - We had a fire in the cabin yesterday and this morning the passengers are all crowding around the stove again -
Passed the mouth of the little Cheyenne before I was up - After running about 15 miles came to a sand bar extending across the river, sent the men ashore with the barge and they "cordelled" along shore three or four miles - The yawl was sent out to hunt for the channel, but as the report was unsatisfactory and the wind was blowing quite hard - we returned 
hard crossed out - all day
Completed

SUNDAY, July 1st, 1855.
One of the finest mornings since we left St Louis.
We started early - crossed the bar without trouble, crossed out - and took our barge in tow and steamed on up the river - 
Two hunters were sent ahead of the boat this morning - 
We picked them up about ten O'clock - they had killed only a prairie owl
-Passed the mouth of the "Nord" about 11 O'clock - soon after saw four crossed out - Elk antelope They were in sight some time (1/2 hour) curiosity greater than fear - Passed the mouth of the Grand River at 6 O'clock old Ree village at 7 - 
Very warm afternoon -
Completed

MONDAY, July 2d, 1855.
Fine morning but think it will be very warm - report indians in sight this morning, if true, they are probably Yanctonais who live in the vicinity of Long Lake near Cannon Ball River - Arrived at 11 O'clock at a few Yanctonais' lodges (12) planted corn - 
Col Vaughan made them a present after holding a council in which they expressed themselves friendly -
- Soon after leaving the village we discovered an immense column of smoke rising - it was a signal fire - the telegraph of the prairies - probably being for the purpose of informing hunters of presents -
Completed

TUESDAY, July 3d, 1855.
Pleasant morning, rather cool - Although yesterday morning we had every prospect of a very warm day - the weather changed before noon and we had a hail storm in the afternoon and the night was quite cool - Two deer were shot at yesterday from the boat + missed - 
Passed the mouth of Cannon Ball river at 1/2 past 1 -
Did not stop to examine, but were told by several on board who had been on the stream that round stones from which the river takes it's name could be picked up of different sizes varying from 3 feet Diameter to the size of a musket ball
Completed

WEDNESDAY, July 4th 1855.
Beautiful Morning - last night after the boat stopped went through a point of timber to the prairie - took four hours - got full of thorns - 
At the rising of the sun this morning a gun was fired in honor of the day - We often see the work of the Beaver along the banks - about noon passed the first vein of coal - 
Better Timber - 
The day is being celebrated quietly + pleasantly - had a very fine dinner, champagne, + other wines - We see a great many ducks, geese +c etc - Col Vaughan's interpreter killed a deer at a wooding place
Completed

THURSDAY, July 5th, 1855.
Cool night but a very pleasant morning, Had venison for breakfast
Arrived at the "Ree" village at 1/2 past 12 - 
Col V- Vaughan distributed the annual present - 
Left at 1/2 past 7 -
Ran on four miles to the Mandan village -
After distributing presents left at 10 O'clock in the evening -
Dwindled down, destroyed by diseases from larger nation to forty souls - Now number about 300 -
Singular people - blue eyes, yellow hair and grey?
We did not run far before stopping - for the night -
Completed

FRIDAY, July 6th, 1855.
Last  night was another cool night and this is another delightful morning
We left Mr. Hodgkins at Fort Clark - took on board Mr. Dawson of Ft Benton and four others - Bad news from Ft. Union - 
Yesterday saw a vein of coal at Ree village - 
Col. C- [[Cumming] sent two men from Ft. Pierre to the peaceful Sioux asking them to meet him at Ft. Clark nothing heard of men or indians, left order at Ft. Clark to send the men on to Fort Union if they come in soon - 
Wind commenced to blow very hard and we were obliged to lay up for the whole afternoon
Completed

SATURDAY, July 7th, 1855.
Very pleasant Morn - We arrived at Fort Berthold at nine O'clock A.M. - This is the "Gros Ventres" village or "Mintners"
They number about blank space where he intended to go back and write a number large men long hair caused by unclear - Col. V Vaughan distributed the presents
-Another coal vein here much thicker than at Ft. Clark - 
Left at 12 O'clock - 
We took on board three Blackfeet indians who had been here on a friendly visit also some Gros Ventres - 
One of the Blackfeet is named "Little Dog" and is the one whom Gov. Stevens mentions
A hunter started from Ft. Berthold -
Completed

SUNDAY, July 8th, 1855.
Windy but pleasant
-Buffalo were represented plenty in the vicinity and we are looking at the hills and prairies along the river anxious to get the first sight of them -
The winds blew us ashore about 12 miles below Knife River, here the first Buffalo were seen - 5 Bulls - 
The men shot a black tail deer, Mr. Chouteau went across the river to look for some Elk horns, met a grizzly and two cubs, did not shoot at her - 
Started on and found when we counted noses, that we had left six men who had strayed off - they had a long run -
Completed

MONDAY, July 9th, 1855.
Beautiful morning - saw a drove of fifty Elk and soon after breakfast the first Buffalo were in sight from the boat - 
We are constantly in sight of game - We gather quantities of Berries called Service berries - They are very delicious - I found a skull last night on the hills and some pieces of petrified wood
We are passing through a portion of the Marais river
See many veins of coal or lignite - 
Some prospect of getting to mouth of Yellow Stone tomorrow
Completed

TUESDAY, July 10th, 1855.
Beautiful morning again but quite warm - 
We got aground soon after breakfast and were detained about two hours had to spar off - 
We stopped to wood crossed out - about a few miles below the mouth of Muddy Creek, one of the men (unclear) went ashore and killed a fine fat bull - The boat stopped to get him - 
The warmest day for sometime - 
Passed Vermillon Hills before dark - 
Muddy R- River said to be the northern point
Completed

WEDNESDAY, July 11th, 1855.
Was awakened this morning by the boy asking if I wanted to see a buffalo killed - 
Got up and found a small drove, thirty or forty, in the river - 
We caught 8 calves and took on board the carcases of two yearling bulls 1 Heifer and one old cow - about 8 O'clock came in eight of an immense herd grazing upon the bluff - I shot 2 dead and wounded one - 
Passed the mouth of the Yellow Stone and arrive at Ft Union at 7 O'clock
Completed

THURSDAY, July 12, 1855.
We could not land at the Fort, stopping on the opposite side - Water very low - Cool morning - The fort is built of wood with two stone bastions - about five miles above the mouth of the Y.S. Yellowstone River - 
The boat is unloading today crossed out - and the river unclear about the Fort presents quite a lively appearance boats crossing +c. etc. -
Not an indian lodge in sight - 
Not very well -
Completed

FRIDAY, July 13th, 1855.
A slight shower of rain this morning but soon cleared off - 
The steamboat is preparing to get off - 
Will leave about noon - The appearance upon the side of the river where the Fort stands is materially changed - 
When yesterday there was not a soul today at ten O'clock stood 350 lodges of Assiniboins containing about 3500 souls - Took dinner on the steamboat and took leave of the officers of the boat, and Mr. Roche who returns from here, being disgusted with the trip in prospection, and crossed over to the Fort
Completed

SATURDAY, July 14th, 1855.
Last night we had a very heavy rain, accompanied with wind & thunder - 
We were met very kindly by the "Fur Comp." people at the Fort. The indians are lounging about the Fort outside and within - 
Col. Cumming has concluded to go by land to Ft. Benton - Mr. Wilson and myself go by water - a long tedious trip - 
The boats are loading up on the opposite side of the river - A slight sprinkle of rain about dark - accompanied by thunder and lightning -
Completed

SUNDAY, July 15th, 1855.
Sunday at Fort Union has been only observed by late rising and only two meals of victuals, every thing else went on as usual on account of the desire to start the boats as soon as possible - 
The Indians have been dancing nearly all day in the fort - 
No particular difference in the dance from other nations I have seen - it wound up with a buffalo dance, which is very much like the others except the dancers wear the skin of a buffalo head - 
Weather quite cool towards night
Completed

Beautiful morning - did not sleep very well on account of the howling of the dogs, of which there are a great number about the Fort. They are of the Esquimeaux Breed introduced by the Assiniboins who got them from Red River indians - The Ass. are poor in horses but high in dogs - 
Mr. Meldrum is here he is a Scotchman by birth - A Crow by adoption of which nation he is a chief - he has been in the country about thirty years - is a very intelligent man about fifty years of age - 
Boats are nearly ready to leave - will get off tomorrow
Completed

TUESDAY, July 17th, 1855.
Fine morning, rather cool.
The boats are loaded and we will get off today - 
We left Fort Union at 12 O'clock precisely, went about 1 1/2 miles and stopped at 2 O'clock to dine - Started on at three - 
Got aground once before dinner which detained us sometime - 
We ran on till dark when we stopped for the night - We have four hunters out - Two on each side of the river
They came in tonight with one deer, killed another which they hung up to keep it out of the way of the wolves
Completed

WEDNESDAY, July 18th, 1855.
Fine cool morning - 
We are two boats the crew of the larger one (80 tons) on which I am a passenger consists of 39 men on the cordelle - 2 cooks - 4 men with poles - 1 pilot and one supercargo - The men of the other is 24 men on cordelle, 2 cooks, 2 men with poles, 1 capt. and 1 supercargo  - 
Last night 4 men deserted from the other boat and two from ours The hunters came in to breakfast with one deer, the other eaten by crossed out - the wolves a Bear. - 
We did not make much progress - stopped early to re/model the steering oar
Completed

THURSDAY, July 19th, 1855.
Beautiful Warm morning, We have plenty of veinson now and expect to get Buffalo soon - we are not far enough from the fort yet - 
Started on early - sent a man back to the fort with letters also for tools as it is the opinion of the managers that we are so heavily laden it will be necessary to build a boat - Men returned from the fort in afternoon bringing various tools which we had sent for - 
Stopped early - went out hunting a short distance saw nothing but tracks
Completed

FRIDAY, July 20th, 1855.
Fine morning - quite warm - our hunters left the boat early, came in to breakfast with an elk - All of them had been on one side this morning We crossed two with three (3) horses on the opposite side - Bluffs nearly the same here as below - White stone (sand with an occasional vein of lignite - and wide? brick stone - Water is getting clearer - Squaws went on shore and brought on board quantity of round balls like marbles - also some yellow crossed out - goosebe currants
I left the boat after dinner with my friend Mr. Wilson, after walking 2 miles I saw a Bull back on the prairie - killed him, went out for it from boat + found the hunters had dressed it - hot - saw a beaver? hill -
Completed

SATURDAY, July 21st, 1855.
Lovely morning. The hunters on the left bank brought in two Antelope last night - had some of the liver for breakfast - Man caught a large rattlesnake 11 rattles - 
Hunting killed a buffalo bull today and one antelope.
The man in charge says we came about 18 miles yesterday - 
I went a short distance but saw no game, picked up several round balls similar to those found on Cannon ball river - 
This is the warmest day since we left Fort Union -
Completed

SUNDAY, July 22d, 1855.
Another beautiful morning with prospect of a warm day, We stopped to breakfast about one mile below the mouth of the Big Muddy, After breakfast we went on a few hundred yards and made a short stop at some old wintering houses, I went ashore with my glass and discovered smoke in a point above mouth of Big Muddy, supposed to be indians as the crossed out - men hunters report having seen sign yesterday - 
Saw a buffalo Bull in the mire on the opposite side of the river
Mr. Wilson, Doct H- Hayden + myself took the yawl and crossed to him - he was very poor and we did not disturb him
Completed

MONDAY, July 23d, 1855.
Last night we were troubled with musquitoes for the first time - 
The hunters on the right bank came in with one common + 1 Black tail deer last night - the others we have not heard from at 10 O'clock this morning the last we saw of them they brought us six young geese yeasterday noon which they had killed with sticks - 
The hunters on the left bank came in after noon with 1 Beaver Deer +c etc. had met with no accident, merely missed the boat last night - 
The others killed 3 Bulls and two deer today. We have plenty of meat but would like to see buffalo more plenty -
Completed

TUESDAY, July 24th, 1855.
Musquitoes last night
Yesterday was a very hot day. The hottest since we left the Fort, and this morning has every appearane of being the forerunner of a still more oppressive one - We are going from 10 to 15 miles per day - 
Doct. Hayden went ashore at Chardon's? Creek and reporteed Buffalo in sight, I went off with Mr. Wilson but did not get any as they crossed the river before we reached them, The hunters killed 5 cows on one bank and 6 on the other - 
At dark a light sprinkle of rain - 
Made a very poor run today
Completed

WEDNESDAY, July 25th, 1855.
No musquitoes last night, slept very well, At ten O'clock we stopped to build a boat, our boats are drawing too much water and we are compelled to build another out of green timber - It is a fine cool morning and prospect of a very pleasant day - One of the men caught a young beaver just before we stopped, I have been watching him eat - he is a very intelligent looking little fellow - 
The large boat was unloaded today - saws files and other preparation made for boat building
Completed

THURSDAY, July 26th, 1855.
We put up a sort of a tent last night, composed of six forks covered with a cloth used in the boats for covering the goods - soon after we had it arrayed the winds raised and came near blowing it away - 
The wind blew for an hour - And this morning it is quite cool - The hunters went out before breakfast and killed one elk and one antelope, we sent a man across the river to place a letter on the route Col. Cumming is supposed to travel, to inform him of our situation - The hunters brought in today 5 cows, 1 Elk, 2 deer and 1 antelope - I went 2 or three miles from camp - saw 3 Buffalo and 3 Elk Killed nothing
Completed

Friday, July 27th, 1855

   Fine morning it has looked like rain for a day or two but has all proven to be windy -  this is a clear windy day - The men commenced to saw plank for boat to-day - The work

progresses slowly -

  As we have considerable meat on hand, the hunters did not go out today -
  After dinner we had two straight showers accompanied by heavy wind - the meat was all consumed to-day the men eat enormous quantities of buffalo meat -
  Several of them [?provided?] hooks and lines and caught a great many catfish after supper -
Completed

Cool, pleasant morning  Mr. Nilson? & myself walked out to to the prairie this morning after breakfast but saw no game -- Doct Hayden has klled and stunned several species of small birds -- Clouded up and looked much like rain but -- The hunters came in during the afternoon with 10 antelope and two Buffalo Bulls -- The young beaver, which one of the men caught, the day we got here -- died this afternoon, -- We had no rain to-day, notwithstanding the strong indications --
Completed

Beautiful Morning --
I worked most of the forenoon skinning the beaver which died -- River (one of the hunters) caught an Olo one? last night in a trap and one the night before -- The men are as unclear as usual -- some? are too anxious to get along to lose a day -- The hunters went out to give their horses an opportunity to unclear but saw game and gave chase, came in with 1 Bull 1 cow and two deer -- This has been a very pleasant day indeed. Mr. Kipp is complaining
Completed

A very pleasant but a very warm morning.The first sound this morning I heard was the saws. They are getting on very well with the boat, bottom nearly planked --
We see buffalo from our camp on both sides of the river, they are probably straggling bulls -- The winds blew very hard all the afternoon -- Doct. Hayden crossed the river to see if the letter had been disturbed?, but did not find the place. The bottom of the boat finishes to-day
Completed

A very pleasant but quite windy morning. -- The boat bottom was turned over this morning, and they commenced putting on the knobs and planking to-day -- Some persons appeared on the opposite side of the river at 1/2 past nine this morning -- proved to be Col. Cumming & party -- 4th day from Fort Union, they came over to see us and we rerurned the visit after dinner and were treated very kindly, they expect to reach Fort Benton in 20 days from here -- The hunters killed three deer 2 of them Blacktail
Completed

Rainy morning -- it commenced in the night rains very little rather a sprinkle than a rain -- Col. C-'s party was off before I was up -- We learned from Col. that opposition boat only reached the [?Pie?] village -- The hunters went out and brought in 1 cow 1 deer and 7 antelope -- A shower passed over us during the afternoon -- considerable rain fell -- The boat was planked to-day -- will be off in three or four days -- the weather is quite cool for this season
Completed

Thursday, August 2d, 1855
A very cold morning.  We stayed by a large fire to keep comfortable.  
We discovered a band of buffaloes on the bluffs about six miles below camp, the hunters set out after them - The Doct. Mr. Wilson & myself crossed the river We saw several large bands of buffaloes.  The Doctor and Mr. Wilson attempted to approach them but did not succeed. The hunters returned with four fat cows and one young bull.  Revais took a beaver out of his trap, on his way back home.
Completed

Friday, August 3d, 1855
Beautiful clear morning.
Revais caught an old beaver last night and Bouché a young one.
The boat was caulked and launched today about four o'clock.  Leaks somewhat will probably become tight after remaining in the water a short time.
We saw two buffaloe come to drink on the opposite side of the river but as we had plenty of meat we did not try to shoot them.
This was a very pleasant day, clouded over near night.
Load the boats tomorrow
Completed

Saturday, August 4th, 1855
Another fine morning.  It sprinkled rain in the night, but all clear this morning.

 We loaded the boats, found [?] one leaked much.  the hunters brought in two coneys.
  I went a short distance from camp and discovered large band of of Buffaloe - returned to oamp for Mr. Wilson, who went out with me accompanyied by Dr. [?] but as they are poor hunters we killed none.
 Thousands of buffalos were crossing the river in sight of our camp and with their bellowing and [?] we had music all night.
Completed

103 miles from Fort Union
Sunday, August 5th, 1855
We were off this morning at four O'clock.  We did not regret leaving our camp for we had all become very tired of it.  The morning cloudy but not unpleasant.
In the confusion of the hunt, last night, I lost my knife which I regret much as I shall not be able to get as good an one.
We pass many beaver lodges and cuttings.
The hunters brought in today 3 coneys and one black tail deer - When we stopped for the night, the prairies in sight were literally covered with buffaloe.  
The men on the [?] killed 5 rattlesnakes before dinner -
We have come 16 miles to-day.
Completed

Monday, August 6th, 1855
It commenced to rain before daylight and continued until about 8 O'clock  -
One of the hunters (Rouchy) did not come to the boat last night.  We overtook him this morning about 10 O'clock, he had killed four fat Elk -
We  saw thousands of buffaloe feeding on the prairie this forenoon.
Passed "Riviere au Tremble" at ½ past 3 O'clock.
The hunters killed today 1 Antelope  1 Deer & two coneys - A heavy storm came on and we camped early having come about 14 miles today.  it has been quite warm.
Completed

Tuesday, August 7th, 1855
It rained a great portion of the night - This morning was cold and windy; the boats started on but after going about one mile, found the winds too heavy and were compelled to lay by -  We were detained by he wind until five O'clock when we went on about two miles and camped for the night -

 The hunters brought 2 deer - 1 Black tail and one [?] Game is plenty but we only kill for food.

The water is getting much clearer - timber plenty on the banks of the river -
The water is said to be lower than has ever been since the whites have [?] here
Completed

Wednesday, August 8th, 1855
It sprinkled some this morning but soon cleared up - but was showery the whole day.
The hunters brought in two coneys, four black tail deer and one [?] and more - Also caught one large beaver -
During the afternoon large droves of buffaloe were in sight.  Mr. Dawson thought he had discovered some in the water, under the bank, some distance ahead.  I went out with him but the buffaloe  turned into stumps, I shot a sage rabbit an animal similar to the English hare -
The river is rising quite rapidly.
The banks are more level and we get along better than at the start.
14 miles     (17)
Completed

Thursday, August 9th, 1855
Was awakened by the rain pattering on our canvass roof. - We saw the "Square Butte" this morning opposite "Milk River" it was probably three days journey by water.  Cleared up -
Mr. Dawson & myself went ashore for a walk.  Killed one deer and wounded two Elk.
We found great quantities of black currants, very palatable.
The hunters killed two deer did not hunt much as we had plenty of meat - The boats sailed some distance this afternoon -
We came fourteen miles today.
Completed

Friday, August 10th, 1855
It commenced to rain last night about ten O'clock, rained nearly all night, and continues all day until about five O'clock.
We started on - went about two hundred yards, when it commences to rain again and we stopped for the night.
A dreary, dismal day - rained so that we could nave no dinner cooked, and we had no remedy for hunger but to sleep off our appetites.
It cleared up just sunset and we hoped for a pleasant day tomorrow.
No hunting today and we ate all the meat for supper.
Completed

Saturday, August 11th, 1855
A cool, clear morning.

 I went out with Mr. Dawson and a shower passed over us which wet us through to the skin and we got to the boat tired, wet and hungry for dinner; the hunters had killed a buffaloe and we had plenty of meat again.
 The river is very crooked, a person could walk on the shore in one hour as far as the boat goes in a day -----------The hunters killed today four bulls, three cows. two calves, two deer, one elk and one beaver. ---
  We saw a Grizzly on a sand bar, fired several shots at him but did not stop him  We came 18 miles today

120
Completed

Sunday, August 12th, 1855
Fine Morning - quite cool.
Revais caught two beaver last night -
We had a meeting at dinner; it appears that orders had been given to the cook to save the corn until we should arrive at the "bad lands"  When we stopped to dine and the men found nothing but boiled meat, they rebelled - the matter was compromised by giving them a biscuit of  hard bread each and the promise of corn hereafter as long as it should last -
The hunters killed one Elk, three common & 1 BlackTail deer, and one cow.  We travelled about seventeen miles -
Completed

Monday, August 13th, 1855
A very cool morning, every man with an overcoat on who was fortunate enough to have one - 
I took a long walk and shot a bull but did not get him -
We made a very good run, the wind blew quite fresh in the afternoon and our sails assisted us much -
The hunters report having shot a bear but did not get him. They brought in two cows, one elk, one deer and one antelope.
Mr. Dawson shot the antelope - Doct. Hayden has made a collection of petrified sea shells here -
We came twenty two miles today.
Completed

Tuesday, August 14th, 1855
A cold, misty, miserable morning - Buffaloe are still very plenty - It is getting quite tiresome, we have so much unpleasant weather, but we play BackGammon, chess and cards and by such means get through with the days -
I walked out to the hills and found a few curiosities in the way of petrified shells -
We came very well today -
The hunters killed seven blacktail deer and one common -
Passed the mouth of Porcupine River at 10 O'clock -
Made twenty miles
Completed

Wednesday, August 15th, 1855
A very pleasant morning but still a little cool -
We came about two miles and were compelled to stop on account of wind - I walked out about four miles with Mr. Davidson and collected some few shells - Ammonites, &c.
We started on late in the afternoon and ran about two miles and camped for the night.
The hunters killed three deer on the right bank of the river. -
"Bouche" slept out on the other side. -
An old Buffaloe came to the bank on the opposite side, we pelted him with balls and he walked off -
Completed

Thursday, August 16th, 1955
A cold clear morning, heavy white frost last night - We started early and arrived at  "Milk River" at ½ past nine O'clock - We found Bouche here - he had killed two deer and one Grizzly - had also trapped one beaver -
I walked across the point with Mr. Dawson & shot three buffaloe and one deer - The hunters killed one cow and two Elk -
The boat has a good deal of difficulty in getting along owing to the low water consequently we only made twelve miles.
Completed

Friday, August 17th, 1855
This is the finest morning we have had for a long time, weather moderated so that we could be out without an overcoat.  -
I took a long walk in the afternoon and should have been compelled to sleep out the night if they had not sent the yawl up stream about two miles, after me -
I killed two deer and brought their skins on board -
The hunters killed four deer and two bulls, and Bouché trapped one Beaver -
We made about fourteen miles -
Completed

Saturday, August 18th 1855
This was another beautiful morning - Bouche cut his knee yesterday and was not able to hunt, another man went in his place - Bear are very plenty but I have not met any yet - Revais saw five yesterday in one bande - I took a walk in the forenoon and killed a fine, fat male Antelope.
We did not get a very early start this morning and what with crossing the river often &c. did not make but thirteen miles -
The hunters killed three elk and Revais trapped one beaver -
They also killed two bulls, but only took the tongues.
14
Completed

Sunday, August 19th, 1855
This morning cloudy, and looked somewhat like rainy continues cloudy throughout the day but did not rain.
I walked all day, shot a fine deer but he was in the river and sunk instantly -
Saw the first pine to-day.  Country is very poor and no buffaloe in sight except a few bulls -
Wolves are very plenty both white and grey
The hunters killed three Elk and one deer -
We started very early and made the best run since we left the Fort, twenty two miles -
Revais trapped two beavers and caught a young one with his hands -
(25)
Completed

Monday, August 20th, 1855
This was a very pleasant morning and continued so throughout the day -
I walked nearly all day did not shoot anything -
I found one pair of Elk horns and hid them intending to take them down in the spring if I should go down -
We are entering the "Bad lands" although we are not yet up to what is properly called "Mauvaises Terres" by the men who reside in this country -
The hunters illed two Elk, two black tail deer and three common - We came thirteen miles.

14
Completed

Tuesday, August 21st, 1855
Another beautiful morning quite warm -
Mr. Rose (one of the hunters) killed an Elk yesterday and I went for the horns this morning, as he represented them to be fine ones, but I found them rather inferior - I cached them however -
Having walked most of the time for two days I concluded to rest -
The hunters brought on board three Elk and five deer -
We made a very good days run - Eighteen miles
Yesterday saw the first pine - Also shot the first pelican -
Completed

Wednesday, August 22d, 1855
Another fine morning
We are getting in sight of the "round butte" - that is some say they can see it, it is called halfway for our Fort Union to Fort Benton so in two or three days we shall be on the "last half", and all glad of it.
This is the dullest day I have experienced on the trip -
Another poor days run, having made only ten miles -
The hunters on left bank unexpectedly found a band of Cows and killed four - brought in today in all four cows & four deer -
Completed

Thursday, August 23d, 1855
This is a very pleasant day - We are now in plain sight of the "Round Butte -
The water is so very low that we have much difficulty
We consumed the meat that was brought aboard yesterday and the hunters came in with only one deer -
I hear the hunters speak of having seen prairie dog villages, I have not been fortunate enough to discover any yet     one deer
13 miles
Completed

Friday, August 24th, 1855
This morning were again aroused by the rain pattering on our canvass roof -
It rained all day not steadily [?] showering-
We travelled very little owing to low water and rain and only made Eight miles - 
The hunters killed five black tail deer and one fawn so that we have plenty of meat for tomorrow -
Revais also shot one small beaver -
We camped about one mile above the "Round Butte" - We are now in the "Bad lands" and the scenery is most romantic -
Completed

Saturday, August 25th, 1855
Still showery and quite cold -
We were troubled again to-day by low water but as we had [?]  and wind we  [?] [?] and went quite rapidly some of the time. -
I went out in the afternoon and found a prairie dog village, succeeded in getting only one although I shot several - they sit upon a little mound formed by the earth which they throw out of the hole and the moment they are shot they drop into their holes even if shot through the head -
The hunters brought in one deer and one fawn -
We came seventeen miles
Completed

Sunday, August 26th, 1855
This is a beautiful cloudless morning, and the warm rays of the sun are much pleasanter than the cold rain of yesterday.
We had no meat for dinner, but pork which is not called meat in this country -
We have a very hard time getting along - the [?...lers?] often are compelled to get over boarde and push and lift the boats over the sand bars - 
We came to a rapid which after a thorough trial we found we could not pass without lighting, so we dropt down to a convenient place for unloading and stopped for the night having made but four miles
The hunters on left bank killed one deer and one bull
Completed

Monday, August 27, 1855
Beautiful morning - We unloaded our boats, passed the rapids and loaded again before dinner -  I went out a short distance from the river and found several prairie dog villages -
The hunters on right bank of the river did not come in last night, the others killed today one deer - 
A great may fish were caught last night so we had fish for breakfast and dinner - they were very good catfish and white fish -
We started out and made three miles during the afternoon - slow  travelling. seven miles in two days!
Hunters on right bank still absent -
Completed

Tuesday, August 28th, 1855
It was quite windy during the night with a sprinkle of rain, cool morning but not uncomfortably so. -
The hunters on right bank made their appearance this morning, while we were taking breakfast, with three black tail deer, three common and one large beaver -
The hunters report game plenty about two days travel from here with boats -
We did not make a very good run in the forenoon but in the afternoon the wind sprung up and we travelled rapidly for us, - 
Made 16 miles today
Completed

Wednesday, August 29th, 1855
Cloudy morning but not very unpleasant -
I went out in the forenoon and shot three wolves in a prairie dog village, they were watching the dogs waiting I suppose to surprise one far enough from his hole to overtake him before he could reach it, I am told they destroy a great number in this way -
In the afternoon I went some distance ahead of the boat and stopped to fish - caught a fine string of cat & flat fish and lost my line - The hunters killed 2 common deer, one blacktail, one bull and one beaver -We made fifteen miles.
Completed

Thursday, August 30th, 1855
A beautiful, clear morning we made four miles before breakfast
We are again getting to points heavily timbered and will soon have game plenty [crossed out: again]
I went ahead of the boats to fish, they did not overtake me at dinner time but I met the hunters who had killed buffaloe so I dined on buffaloe hump and marrow fat - I caught a fine string of fish.
The wind commenced blowing and the boats had to stop about two O'clock having come but ten miles - the hunters killed five bulls, one Elk one blacktail and nine common deer -
Completed

Friday, August 31st, 1855
Wind still blowing and we are compelled to remain "in status quo." but meat is plenty so that we don't grumble -
I saw many bear tracks yesterday but no bears - found some beautiful petrified shells -
Wind died away at one O'clock and we travelled about seven miles -
We begin to see plenty of buffaloe again.
The hunters killed to-day two cows, two com. deer and three black tail.
The hunters say the "Muscle Shell" is near, in sight from the bluffs.
Completed

Saturday, September 1st, 1855
A cloudy morning but soon cleared off -
I went out with Messrs. Wilson & Dawson to fish, I caught some fine ones, on my return to the boat, I found an express had arrived from the Fort, no news, all arrived safe.
Gov. Stevens sent me two horses, so that I shall be able to ride out occasionally -
We passed the Mouth of the "Muscle Shell" River at ½ past four O'clock -
The hunters killed five cows and one deer -
We came fourteen miles -
Completed

Sunday, September 2d, 1855
A very, pleasant morning, quite wrm -
I started the express back to the fort this morning -
I went on ahead of the boats in the afternoon and caught a fine string of cat and white fish. -
The river is good again and we go on very well -
The hunters killed two cows -
We came sixteen miles -
Culbertson is expected hourly from Ft. Benton
Completed

Monday, September 3d, 1855
Another beautiful warm morning,
I went out and caught a string of fish in the forenoon and on my return found Culbertson and Vaughan had arrived with four men and six horses, nothing new -
They remained with us the balance of the day. 
We only made thirteen miles to-day 
The hunters killed two cows and four deer
Completed

Tuesday, September 4th, 1855
A very fine, warm morning -
Mr. Culbertson & party made preparation to start but did not get off - They camped with us again -
I let Mr. Wilson take one of the horses Gov. Stevens sent me, he is to go up with the party -
We took the wrong channel once and it detained us much - so that we only made nine miles - 
Game is still plenty the hunter killed two cows and a fawn.
Completed

Wednesday, September 5th, 1855
We got off early this morning -
Left Culbertson and party at camp but they soon passed us -
The buffaloe came to water opposite where we camped and kept up a continual roaring during the night - I went out fishing in the forenoon caught plenty - I saw a bear and an elk but too far off to shoot -
It rained some during the afternoon -
The hunters killed three cows, one calf and three blacktail deer -
We came fourteen miles
Completed

Thursday, September 6th, 1855
It rained during the night and is still cloudy this morning -
It continued showery throughout the day, but notwithstanding the rain I went out and caught the finest string of fish yet - I saw several Elk and deer but did not try to kill any -
The hunters killed four cows, one black tail deer and two common deer -
We came thirteen miles -
The [?points?] are getting much better   I saw plenty of fine grass to-day -
Completed

Friday, September 7th, 1855
It rained some during the night and this morning was so foggy that we did not start until after breakfast when it cleared off.
After going about three miles we arrived at what is called the "Bad bend", so called from the great number of snags,  here the wind commenced blowing and we laid by all the balance of the day - I walked out to a high butte and could see the "Little Rocky Mountain" apparently quite near, but probably thirty miles distant.
Game is getting scarce again -
The hunters killed to-day two blacktail deer and one beaver -
Completed

Saturday, September 8th, 1855
A beautiful morning and we were off early, passed the bad bend and took breakfast, found some difficulty on account of low water but were not detained long -
We unexpectedly came to a plenty of game again - We travelled along very well, were detained some by bad places in the river -
We made thirteen miles.
The hunters killed nine cows, one calf, two blacktail deer, three common deer and three bulls so that we again have more meat than we need -
Completed

Sunday, September 9th, 1855
A very pleasant morning   We had another bad place this morning and only went one mile before breakfast directly after breakfast the wind sprung up ahead and the boats could not leave, the wind [?] [?] the passed [?"Durmelle's?] Rapids" and camped at [?"Annabelle's?] islands" having come about three miles.
I started fishing in the morning, forgot my bait, killed a buffaloe bull and took a piece of the meat baited with it and caught a fine string of white fish and three soft shell turtles. 
The hunters killed one Elk only, they did not hunt, we had a supply
Completed

Monday, September 10th, 1855
Cloudy morning, appearance of rain before night.  We started early and made three mlles before breakfast.
Do et Hayden yesterday discovered some good coal.
It turned quite cold before noon.  We ran on until about four O'clock came to a bad place and concluded to stop until morning, at "calves head island" having come nine miles -
The hunters killed two cows, one elk and one deer -
Completed

Tuesday, September  11th, 1855
Beautiful morning, 
We ran up about two miles today, found we could not cross the rapids without difficulty, so concluded to send two boats ahead to the "Judith River" with small cargoes, from which place they will return here and then the three boats will be able to take the balance up without unloading at the different rapids.  Plenty of good coal here.
The hunters killed two Elk and two black tail deer.
Completed

Wednesday, September 12th, 1855
The two boats started early this morning, we expect them back in five days - We have here Mr. Kipp and myself - one cook, two watchmen, "Bouché & Michel" (hunters) and Bouché's squaw & child.
I went out after breakfast on to a high butte and could see the two boats far ahead going well.
After dinner two indians made their appearance.  They were spies belonging to a war party of thirty five Blackfeet, they were returning from the Crows, where they had stolen ten horses.  They came straggling in until we had the whole party with us.  Not very welcome visitors.
Completed

Thursday, September  13th, 1855
It is a beautiful day, the nights are getting quite cool, froze water last night 1/4 inch
Our visitors left apparently well satisfied and if they don't return we shall be equally well pleased.
Bouché took two beaver out of his traps this morning.   I amused myself during the day, picking the heads to preserve.
Michel had set his traps above, went to look at them and found the indians had been to them and taken out two beaver but left the traps.
The hunters did not go out hunting today.
Completed

Friday, September 14th, 1855
Cold, cloudy morning.
Bouché visited his traps, got one large beaver.  Michel found none.
Bouché went out hunting and killed one deer and returned.  no fresh sight of indians, think they have all left and our horses are safe.
It is very lonely and a large number of ravens constantly flying over our heads with their mournful croaking, make it even still more solitary -
The day passes very quietly - I caught a few fish
Completed

Saturday, September 15th, 1855
A fine morning.
Bouché visited his traps and found one very large beaver -
The wolves serenade us nightly and I am heartily tired of their music.  the horses got frightened in the night - probably a bear as we found a bear track this morning, but no indians.
I went out and caught a few fish, very poor place for them.
Bouché and Michel went hunting, returned having killed one cow, one calf and a young bull - reported indian sign, shortly after, a war party of seven Blackfeet made their appearance
Completed

Sunday, September 16th, 1855
Cool cloudy morning
The warparty staid with us all night and left this morning after breakfast.  They had been to the "Crows" but had taken neither horses nor scalps.
Bouché caught one beaver again
The hunters went out in the afternoon and killed one deer.
It remained cloudy and cool throughout the day -
The day passes quietly - no indians and no excitement -
Completed

Monday, September 17th, 1855
It commenced raining in the night and this morning is pouring down in earnest - it makes it quite unpleasant for us as we have no shelter except on the boat and consequently are deprived of the fire.  Bouché visited his traps but found nothing -
The leaves are turning yellow and add to the melancholy appearance of every thing around -
It continues to rain through the day,
We looked for the boats to return to-day but they did not make their appearance.
Completed

Tuesday, September 18th, 1855
This morning was much surprised on looking out to find about two inches of snow on the ground and a dreary prospect indeed the hills presented, being covered with snow, to persons who had yet a long distance to travel in this desert country.
It continued snowing until night -
Just dark we hear oars and supposed the boats were returning, but it proved to be Mr. Dawson with a skiff and three men, the Skiff is from fort Benton and is to go on to Fort Union -
Completed

Wednesday, September 19th, 1855
It snowed considerably last night - cleared off quite cool this forenoon - Mr. Dawson reports the boats making slow progress and no probability of their return under two or three more days - Mr. Kipp goes down to Fort Union in the skiff.  Will leave to-morrow morning -
Bouché wounded a bear and after dinner we all went out to try and get him, we raised him about three hundred yards from the camp shot him again but he made off -
Bouché caught a large beaver
Completed

Thursday, September 20th, 1855
Rainy foggy morning cleared off quite warm about nine O'clock and the skiff started down.
They brought the news of a battle having been fought between the Crows and Gros Ventrez just above here in which nine Crows were killed and two Gros Ventrez -
This was a very beautiful day but a species of fly, very small, were swarming around us continually and were quite annoying -
We hope to see the boats here to-morrow -
Bouché got a large beaver in his trap but he gnawed his leg off -
Completed

Friday, September 21st, 1855
Another very fine day -
We look now every moment for the boats - we are getting very tired of this place -
The two hunters went out to dig out a beaver lodge but did not succeed.  Bouché caught one in his trap - They went below, to hunt, after dinner but did not kill anything.  Game is getting very scarce about here -
I took a long walk but saw nothing
Completed

Saturday, September 22d, 1855
Cloudy morning.
It rained a very little during the night - I went out to the prairie dog village and shot two, skinned them and preserved their skulls -
Bouché caught another large beaver this morning -
We live now upon beaver, have no other kind of meat -
Mr. Dawson and myself took a walk out on to the hills to look for the boats but no boats in sight -
Completed

Sunday, September 23d, 1855
A beautiful, clear morning.
Michel caught his first beaver, to-day.
Bouché went  out and killed two black tail deer -
The wind blew from south quite fresh -
We can not imagine what has detained the boats -
We are lying at the foot of the "Bad lands" - can see them from the bluff -
We cannot account for the nonarrival of the boats - as their time has long since expired -
Completed

Monday, September 24th, 1855
A slight sprinkle of rain this morning but it soon cleared off with a strong north wind.
We started Michel this morning with orders not to return until he could bring some news of the boats.
This suspense is getting to be very painful, we may be visited by Blackfeet and Crow war parties and we are very shorthanded for a large party of indians.
Bouché went out hunting but killed nothing.
Completed

Tuesday, September 25th, 1855
Another beautiful morning -
Soon after dinner we were surprised by the return of Michel who reported the boats on their return, will probably be here today.
We discovered a band of buffaloe crossing below, but the wind was blowing strong from the north and they got frightened and crossed back - The boats returned about four O'clock and we were very glad to see them - Tomorrow we will once more be on our way.
Completed

Wednesday, September 26th, 1855
A fine morning and we were loaded and off at [?] 1/2 O'clock -
We are out of meat have a little pork but that is not called meat in this country.
Mr. Dawson and myself started out after dinner to try to kill something - we saw two "big horns" but did not succeed in getting a shot at them - I raised a buffaloe bull, he ran towards Mr. Dawson who wounded him in the shoulder.  I followed and killed him, the boats stopped and took him aboard -  Hunters killed one bull and two beaver
We made ten miles
Completed

Thursday, September 27th, 1855
A very pleasant morning.
We stared early and passed "Cow Island" rapids at 3 O'clock.  We stopped there to dine - Mr. Dawson and myself took a long hunt in the hills after "Big horn" -  I shot one but could not get him.
We are now in the "Bad lands" again and big horn are very plenty.
The hunters killed one bull, one blacktail deer and two big horns.
We saw the place where the late battle was fought between the "Crows" and "Gros Ventrez"  I found where a body had been burnt, I picked up from the ashes a jawbone
Came 10 miles
Completed

Friday, September 28th, 1855
It rained a little during the night but this morning was clear and cold - We went about one mile before breakfast and laid bye on account of wind
Started on at one O'clock and travelled about six miles -
The hunters killed one big horn - They killed eight cows and one big horn, also Seven bulls but did not take the meat - I took a walk on ahead of the boats and saw sixteen bighorns in one band upon the top of a high "butte" too far off to shoot one -
Completed

Saturday, September 29th, 1855
A fine morning we started early and made a good run until dinner time when the winds sprung up and we did not start again until about five O'clock -
I walked out and started a bull, mountain lion, and he crossed the river - after dinner I crossed over and killed him
The hunters went out on the bluffs and killed four cows so that we are well supplied with meat again.
We only went a short distance and stopped for the night having made about eight miles.
Completed

Sunday, September  30th, 1855
It rained a little last night again but this morning was all clear and cold -
An express from the fort reached us before breakfast and started back again after he had received his papers - no news from them except they are getting impatient.
We passed "Birds Rapids" today, had to take out some of the freight and were detained so much that we only made about five miles -
The hunters killed two fat bulls
Completed

Monday, October 1st, 1855
A very fine morning - We were at work early but had to pass a rapids so that we did not get far before breakfast.
I went ahead of the boats and caught a fine string of fish.
The hunters killed only one bull to-day.
We are still in the "Bad lands".  We occasionally see a bed of good coal - also the red brick-like [?appearance?] which is seen in the bad lands below the yellow stone
The river is so low that it is almost a constant succession of rapids -
We made about five miles -
Completed

Tuesday, October 2d, 1855
Another very beautiful morning - Passed a rapid before breakfast about 800 yards - Arrived in sight of Dauphin's Rapids (The worst on the Missouri) at about eleven o'clock the wind commenced blowing and we laid by all day. - 
The hunters killed six bulls, some of them very fat -
We travelled about two miles -
It seems impossible to make a whole days travel - the fates are against us -
Bouché killed a bighorn also
Completed

Wednesday, October 3d, 1855.
The wind changed in the night and blew a gale from the south accompanied with rain, but this morning it is north again.
We went about two miles to the foot of "Dauphin's Rapids" where we unloaded our boats partially, preparation to passing the rapids.
It snowed a little during the afternoon and evening.  I caught twenty six white fish while the men were unloading the boats.
The hunters killed a fine young bull near by and then were  roasting meat all night
Completed

Thursday, October 4th, 1855
Whew!!  Cold as Greenland.  Wind blowing a gale and no prospect of getting over these miserable rapids -
Wind continued to blow hard all day and we did not move -
An express reached us from Fort Benton just night.  They were after provisions -
I received a letter from Wilson and one from Col. Cumming.  No news, same old story, little to eat and waiting anxiously for the boat -
The hunters killed nothing although we saw plenty of bulls -
Completed

Friday, October 5th, 1855.
A clear cold morning, water left standing in a tin cup was solid ice this morning - We started over the rapids with the big boat before breakfast - got over with little trouble, except the men were compelled to get into the water occasionally and lift over the rocks, which looked rather hard as their clothing would freeze on them as soon as they came out. - We got the other two boats through before dinner.  After dinner started on once more, bid farewell to Dauphin's rapids for this year and went on about 3 miles.
Completed

Saturday, October 6th, 1855
Mr. Dawson sent Revais to the Judith for meat, Michel returned with some bull meat - We started early this morning but in passing a little rapid one of the boats had the misfortune to break a mast. - We went on to Rondin's Rapids and were again detained by the wind and repairing mast
Sent to the Judith again and the hunter returned with the meat of six very fat cows.  I rode out on to the bluffs before dinner and killed one fat bull, saw plenty of buffaloe, fine grazing country - We [?......ed?] all day at the foot of Rondin's Rapids - at sunset two fine young bulls came running along.  We killed them both.
2 miles
Completed

Sunday, October 7th, 1855
Beautiful Morning - Passed Rondin's Rapids before breakfast - loaded up and started on again.  Went about two miles, passed a small rapid and came to another at which we were again obliged to unload, got over it about three O'clock -
Last evening we were honored with a visit from a Chief of the "Gros Ventrez" with six braves - He said he came to see his Agent.
Made him a small present and he left again this morning
This afternoon another party visited us - We have travelled very well, considering the delays at rapids &c
5 miles
Completed

Monday, October 8th, 1855
Another very fine morning - We got an early start -
About nine O'clock an express reached us from the fort, with the information that the commissioners have concluded to hold the Council at the Judith.
We reached the point where the freight was left by the other boats (opposite the Judith) at three O'clock - here the most of our trouble ends as the boats will be light from here -
We found a fine lot of meat, Revais having killed thirteen cows -
Completed

Tuesday, October 9th, 1855
A very pleasant morning
Commenced unloading the boats -
Found a camp of about forty lodges about a mile from our camp -
A chief called "Big Eagle" camped near us, he was quite sick -
Doct Hayden gave him a dose of blue [?pi...?] 
We expect the Gov. and Col. Cumming every day now -
The Col. wrote that he would be here by Thursday without fail. -
Completed

Wednesday, October 10, 1855
A pleasant morning but rather cool -
After breakfast some of the men crossed the river to get some wood for oars - one of them carelessly fired the point and the wind blowing up stream soon communicated the fire to the trees and the whole point was in a blase, continued to burn all day and presented a beautiful appearance in the evening, some of the trees blasing to their very tops. -
The indians brought us in a quantity of meat  We have more than we know what to do with.
Completed

Thursday, October 11th, 1855
A beautiful morning.  Clear and warm -
Everything quiet and we are now waiting the arrival of the Commis, and indians -
Gov. Stevens arrived from Fort Benton about three O'clock - accompanied by Flathead and Nez Perces Agents - Lansdale and Tappan - also Messrs Adams and Doty -
The Gov. reports the indians near, most of them will be in to-morrow. -
The weather is quite warm -
Completed

Friday, October 12th, 1855
A beautiful, warm morning -
Gov. has his tents up and things begin to present quite a business aspect -  Col. Cumming will be here to-day probably as he did not arrive last night according to appointment - Flatheads, Pend d'Oreilles, Gros Ventres, Nez Perces, Bloods, Piegans and Blackfeet all coming in and mingling together in a friendly manner -
I had the hospitatlity of the Gros Ventres exhibited this evening in a very strange way - which I did not duly appreciate I fear -
Completed

Saturday, October 13th, 1855
A very pleasant morning - Indians still coming in -
Col. Cumming arrived to-day about two O'clock - The comms. are both on the ground now and business will soon commence -
Two Jesuit priests arrived to-day from other side of the mountains, the bring news of some indian difficulties on the other side - seven men killed by the Yakimas. [crossed out: Esquimaux]
Completed

Sunday, October 14th, 1855
This morning was not quite as pleasant as the preceding one, and it turned quite cool about twelve O'clock -
Mr. Culbertson arrived to-day - Mr. Wilson also returned to the boats looking much improved -
It continued old during the day.
Completed

Monday, October 15th, 1855
A very pleasant morning -
Making preparations to hold the council to-morrow -
Blackfeet, Piegans, Bloods, Pend d'Oreilles, Nez Perces, Flatheads, Gros Ventres &c present
Completed

Tuesday, October 16th, 1855
Beautiful morning.
Went into council at 12 O'clock -
The FlatHeads were dissatisfied with the portion of country assigned them and the council adjourned until to-morrow -
The hunter, from the boat with company goods, came to us to-day - reports the boats near will be here to-morrow -
Completed

Wednesday, October 17th, 1855
Cloudy and windy -
Went into Council after issuing some provisions to the different tribes -
The boat mentioned yesterday arrived this morning.  Michel [?Champagnon?] who went  down to pilot her up had received a present of some potatoes & beets from a man from Fort Union, he gave me (11) some which were very acceptable as I had not tasted any for three months -
The treaty was signed at 3 O'clock and "peace prevails" -
Completed

Thursday, October 18th, 1855
A beautiful morning and we were early a work dividing presents for the different tribes [crossed out: nations] viz. Blackfeet, Piegans, Bloods, Gros Ventrez - Cree (1)        [?Contures?], Pend D'Oreilles, Flatheads, Nez Percez and a few [?Snakes?]   We succeeded in dividing the provisions and tobacco to-day - to-morrow we shall probably get through with the goods and next day I shall be off for Fort Burton
Completed

Friday, October 19th, 1855
Very pleasant morning.
We worked hard all day dividing the goods among the different tribes, we succeeded in doing so without creating much dissatisfaction, which is rather strange, as they are very jealous - 
It clouded over after noon and snowed and rained some during the evening
We did not finish dividing the hardware still do it in the morning
Completed

Saturday, October  20th, 1855
A cold morning -
We finished with the Indians this morning.  The Commrs. presenting each chief with a medal -
I left on the boats at 11 O'clock -
Col. C. returns to St. Louis going down in a boat to Fort Union and from there is uncertain whether he will go on down the river or by way of  [?]
Gov. S. returns by land across the mountains to Washington Territory -
We went five miles
Completed

Sunday, October 21st, 1855
It rained quite hard during the night and this morning is cold and wet - We travelled on slowly and came about four miles before noon, it then commenced blowing and we laid by the balance of the day - An indian who is along with us killed a blacktail deer so we have some fresh meat again - We have been living on dried [?meat?] tongues and little [?bosses?]
We have now only thirty five men and with two boats it is very slow work -
Completed

Monday, October 22, 1855
Another cool morning snowing a very little - 
We reached the mouth of Arrow river about 12 O'clock.  it is [?] fifteen miles from the Council ground
We had put on all the men to one boat - after dinner went down and brought up the other one, which took until night.
We see indians crossing the river on horseback occasionally - they are all moving off to buffalo.
The indian killed three Bighorn today -
Completed

Tuesday, October 23d, 1855
Another cold cloudy morning -
We travelled on, but were compelled to put all the men to one boat often, on account of the swift current, so that we only came about five miles during the day - arrived at the crossing place, where the road from Fort Benton to the "Indian" crosses the Missouri, at dark -
Saw some fires about half mile above us, crossed the river and walked up found it was the Gov and party "en route" for home.
I found some fine petrified shells to-day - I think they are of the nautilus species.
Completed

Wednesday, October  24th, 1855
Pleasant morning - The Gov. crossed the river this morning and went on -
After breakfast I went out riding on Mr. [?...'s?] horse - after following the river bank a while I tied the horse and went up on the bluff to hunt "Big horn"  Shot one, a fine buck -
The scenery is grand -  We are in the "bad lands" again but they differ from those of the same name below.  The rocks are in all imaginable shapes, Castles, Steamers &c, &c.  There are also stone walls which appear like a work of art rather than nature -
Came about five miles -
Completed

Thursday, October 25th, 1855
The wind blew very hard during the night and this morning we are unable to move - I took a long ride - went back on to the bluffs and found a beautiful prairie stretching off as far as the eye could reach on both sides of the river -
We did not move to-day with the boats we will be able to go better when we get some assistance from the Fort -
Completed

Friday, October 26, 1855
Wind still ahead, but not blowing very hard -
We started early and met five men with two mules from the Fort about Eight O'clock We will now get on better as we shall not be compelled to double crew so often
We had come about two miles before breakfast we put on the mules but found the wind had increased so much that we stopped and laid by the balance of the day -
No fresh meat - had some dried squashes which were purchased from the [?Red?] indians - [three unclear words]
Completed

Saturday, October 27th, 1855
Beautiful morning - No wind and we were off early and with the assistance of the mules travelled on finely - Passed "The Citadel" before breakfast - it is a rock probably over 100 feet high and fifty or more in diameter at its base - We also passed, to-day, Kipps rapids and the stone wall which crosses the river - I went out hunting Big Horn after breakfast, did not get back to the boats until near four O'clock - I shot three but only got one, the others hid themselves.
We travelled about twenty miles -
Completed

Sunday, October 28th, 1855
Fine morning and we travelled on well until about eleven O'clock when the commenced blowing and we stopped the rest of the day having come about ten miles - The indian killed one Bighorn -
It turned cold in the afternoon and commenced snowing about four O'clock and a fair prospect of continuing through the night -
We saw a great number of Gros Ventres indians coming from the prairie and encamping in a point of timber above us on the opposite side of the river -
Completed

Monday, October 29th, 1855
Cool foggy morning snow about four inches deep - We did not start until about eleven O'clock on account of the fog.
Revais went across to the indian camp and got a little fresh buffalo meat
The fog prevents us from going very fast - We made about ten (10) miles
I was visited at night by a Gros Ventres chief, who was not at the treaty, he came to hear the news, staid all night - I gave him some tobacco and vermilion
Completed

Tuesday, October 30th, 1855
A cool clear morning - We travelled until about nine Oclock - then the wind began to blow and we laid by the balance of the day - having come about five miles -
Gros Ventres moving up, in sight above and below - At night the wind lulled and we had a beautiful warm evening - A man came down from the Fort for some small articles for the trade - Mr. Dawson writes that everything is well there -
Completed

Wednesday, October 31, 1855
A beautiful morning.  We got an early start and travelled on finely going about five miles before breakfast
A Gros Ventres camp moved along on the bank opposite to us.  About three miles long - We had a fine view of a wolf chase close to the bank of the river -
The wind was ahead all day but we succeeded in making sixteen miles -
Just at night an express reached us from the Fort, with the news that the Indians on the other side of the mountains had combined and were killing the whites and were intending to [?waylay?] the Gov and party
Completed

Thursday, November 1st, 1855
Fine morning, but wind still ahead - I concluded to go up to the fort with the men who came down last evening - Started from the boats, where I had spent 107 days and after a pleasant ride of about four hours arrived at Fort Benton at 2 O'clock  - A very pleasant site.  The Fort still unfinished, it is built mostly of adobes, it has at present one wood bastion and one unfinished, of adobes - 
Found Mr. Doty here, (one of the Gov's party) waiting for some rifles and ammunition from the boats - he starts back to-morrow -
Completed

Friday, November 2d, 1855
It snowed during the night about one inch - Pleasant morning - Mr. Doty and party left this morning - thinks they will be compelled to winter in the Bitter Root Valley -
Fort Benton is beautifully situated for an indian fort - on a level prairie about one mile wide and several long, not a stick of timber in sight - the wood is brought from the Teton, a tributary of the Masias - distant about two miles - The prairie is surrounded by a ridge of easy ascent - I walked up to it and saw a fine view - Could see the [?Be..?] and Bearspaw mountain in the distance
